When the Godfather was released in 1972, the golden age of Hollywood was long over. Regardless, this film managed to recall that era while at the same time taking advantage of the ever changing times. This film is darker and more grittier than the films of the thirties and forties as such melancholy was starting to become more common in movies. It definitely didn't forget its roots however. The popular film noir style is very evident in this film: not just in the lighting but in the dark subject matter and often bleak themes. And the themes of the movie are indeed bleak. In fact, as people are shot, blown up, and have revenge acted upon them, an inexperienced movie viewer might wonder what the point is. The point is, under the violence and hate, there is a wealth of good: total justification for the mayhem. The Mafia may be murderous and revengeful, but they have values, possibly even more values than normal, law biding citizens.Marlon Brando gives a breathtaking performance as Don Vito Corleone, a man who is vicious and harden, yet you learn to care for the guy and his family enough so that you eventually root for them every time they get their own way. Al Pacino also gives a great performance as Vito's son Michael, who is different from Vito in many ways. As we learn early on, he could care less about his family's business yet we know he will most likely be shoved into it eventually. We will then learn if he is able to control his family or if he will develop a lust for power and revenge that will cause him to fail altogether. Questions like this are what keep the film interesting and moving forward.The well orchestrated characters also help the plot along and at no point do they seem unrealistic: even when they make drastic choices. And this is important since this is a very character driven film. And that's just one of the many strengths seen here. All great films have multiple strengths and this movie is no exception. Many crime films were made before this film as well as after it. The ones that came before were sometimes weighed down with Hollywood glamor while the ones that came after it were often all flash with no substance: relentlessly violent with no reward in the end for the viewer. The Godfather dodges those weaknesses and it also avoids being pretentious and overblown. Just one of the many things that make The Godfather the best movie of the seventies and possibly the best of all time.

The Godfather isn't just a movie-it's a cultural giant that changed cinema forever. Francis Ford Coppola spins a gripping tale of family, loyalty, and power, all set in the smoky, dangerous world of the Italian-American Mafia. With his hushed voice and calm authority, Brando turns the Don into both a loving father and a man you can't refuse. Al Pacino is just as magnetic-his Michael starts off as the clean-cut war hero who changes totally. James Caan explodes as Sonny, full of swagger and temper. And the rest of the cast-Robert Duvall's smooth Tom Hagen, Diane Keaton's conflicted Kay, John Cazale's tragic Fredo-fill every corner with life.The script by Coppola and Mario Puzo is sharp and poetic, loaded with lines people still quote today. And then there's the background score-haunting, romantic, and instantly recognizable, it's the film's heartbeat.The Godfather isn't just about the Mafia-it's about family, choices, and the price of power. Decades later, it still feels fresh, still grabs you by the collar, and refuses to let go. It's not just a classic-it's gold standard.

Francis Ford Coppola's The Godfather isn't just one of the most acclaimed films ever made-it's a towering piece of storytelling that shaped the landscape of American cinema. It also happens to be my third favorite movie of all time, which says a lot, given the sheer number of films I've seen.Based on Mario Puzo's novel, The Godfather tells the story of the Corleone family, an Italian-American mafia dynasty navigating loyalty, power, betrayal, and change. At the heart of it is Michael Corleone (Al Pacino), a war hero reluctantly drawn into the family business, who evolves into something far darker than anyone expects.This film is a masterclass in character development. Pacino's transformation from soft-spoken outsider to cold, calculating don is one of the greatest arcs in film history. Marlon Brando's Vito Corleone, with his iconic gravelly voice and quiet gravitas, is magnetic without ever needing to raise his voice. Every performance-Caan, Duvall, Keaton-adds weight and nuance to the world Coppola creates.The cinematography by Gordon Willis (nicknamed "The Prince of Darkness") bathes the film in shadows and warm ambers, evoking both nostalgia and menace. Every frame feels deliberate, composed like a painting. Nino Rota's score is haunting, instantly recognizable, and soaked in a deep, tragic beauty.What makes The Godfather so powerful isn't just its epic scope or its unforgettable quotes ("I'm gonna make him an offer he can't refuse")-it's how personal it feels. It's about family, identity, legacy, and the corrupting pull of power. The violence, though sudden and brutal, is never gratuitous-it's always in service of the story.And even though the film is set in a world of crime, it somehow finds empathy for its characters. You understand why they do what they do, even if it horrifies you. That moral ambiguity is what elevates it from a gangster film to a meditation on human nature.

Pacino is the film's star and he is excellent and convincing in his transformation from fresh-faced to poker face.
